chapter.title: Importance of self-determination for individuals with LD
chapter.content:
Importance of self-determination for individuals with LD

Self-determination is a particularly important concept for individuals with LD because they often have to work harder to achieve the same level of academic and/or employment success as individuals without LD. Factors that contribute to enhanced self-determination, such as planning for the future, being proactive, and reflecting and readjusting, enable individuals with LD to overcome the challenges they face and to assume greater responsibility for their actions and control over their lives.

chapter.title: Understanding LD and knowing one’s strengths can increase confidence
chapter.content:
Understanding LD and knowing one’s strengths can increase confidence

Factors that promote self-determination can also help increase the confidence and motivation of individuals with LD. For example, knowing oneself, which includes understanding one’s disability and how to explain it to others, and learning to value oneself, which includes becoming aware of one’s strengths, can be particularly important for individuals with LD since they may struggle with low self-esteem and have had to deal with other people’s perceptions of what it means to have LD.

chapter.title: Attributes of self-determination
chapter.content:
Attributes of self-determination

This definition has a lot packed into it. Let’s further explore the attributes of self-determination.

“Self-determination is a combination of skills, knowledge and beliefs that enables a person to engage in goal-directed, self-regulated, autonomous behavior. An understanding of one’s strengths and limitations together with a belief in oneself as capable and effective is essential to self-determination. When acting on the basis of these skills and attitudes, individuals have greater ability to take control of their lives and assume the role of successful adults in our society.” (Field, et. al. 1998)

chapter.title: Exercise: Reflect on your own self-determination
chapter.content:
Exercise: Reflect on your own self-determination

Please take a moment to reflect on your own experiences.

Think about a time when you were self-determined – when you felt capable and effective. This could be any time in your life from childhood on.

  • What was the situation?
  • What factors enabled you to be self-determined?

Now we ask that you please take a minute to write down the situation and the factors that contributed to your ability to be self-determined.

 

Click the forward arrow when you are done with your reflections.

chapter.title: Examples of being self-determinated
chapter.content:
Examples of being self-determinated

Examples of being self-determined during teen and adult years include:

  • deciding to play a sport or develop a hobby;
  • choosing where to go for postsecondary education;
  • asking someone for a date;
  • getting a checking account;
  • deciding to take a job offer; or
  • moving away from home.

Take a moment to compare your situation with those listed.

 

Click the forward arrow when you are ready to move on.

chapter.title: Examples of self-determination support factors
chapter.content:
Examples of self-determination support factors

Examples of factors that may support self-determination in various situations include:

  • having the support of family or friends in making a decision;
  • possessing a belief and understanding of yourself;
  • having a clear plan of action and/or clear goals; and
  • having access to needed resources or information.

Take a moment to compare your situation and factors with those listed.

chapter.title: Reflect on your own lack of self-determination
chapter.content:
Reflect on your own lack of self-determination

Now we ask you to take a moment to reflect on your experiences for a time when you were NOT self-determined – when you felt ineffective or lacking control.

  • What was the situation?
  • What factors interfered with your ability to be self-determined?

Again, take a minute to write down for yourself the situation and the factors that contributed to your inability to be self-determined.

 

Click the forward arrow when you are done recording your reflections.

chapter.title: Examples of not being self-determinated
chapter.content:
Examples of not being self-determinated

Examples of not being self-determined during teen and adult years include:

  • being controlled by parents about what you could wear;
  • being restricted on where you could go;
  • being tracked in school;
  • being with a group of friends who made you feel afraid to disagree or be different; or
  • staying in relationships or jobs that were not satisfying.

Take a moment to compare your situation with those listed.

chapter.title: Examples of self-determination interference factors
chapter.content:
Examples of self-determination interference factors

Examples of factors that may interfere with self-determination in various situations include:

  • low self-esteem;
  • having unclear or conflicting goals;
  • absence of an effective support system;
  • lack of self-knowledge; and
  • barriers to necessary resources or information.

Take a moment to compare your situation and factors with those listed.

Through this exercise, we have begun our exploration into factors that can either inhibit or contribute to self-determination. Before we explore these factors in more depth, let’s consider one important reason why self-determination can be challenging for individuals with LD.
